instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no keyboard or trackpad
threads.message: I got a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that was liquid damaged around the trackpad connector and did not turn on. Trackpad connector was burned on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S4_TPAD_FUSE</SIGNAL>. I cleaned the area and replaced the trackpad connector with a new one. All diode mode readings on the trackpad connector seemed to match a good board now, so I plugged the board in using another known good trackpad and it boots to the OS, but keyboard and trackpad do not work. I rechecked all diode mode values on the trackpad and keyboard connector and made sure there were no broken traces there. With the trackpad connected, I was not getting any voltage on <SIGNAL>TPAD_SPI_EN</SIGNAL>, which comes from the T2 chip. I removed <CHIP>U6855</CHIP> and found I have OL on pin 1, which is not normal. Seems the trace between the T2 chip and pin 1 of <CHIP>U6855</CHIP> is broken. I cannot run a wire without removing the T2 chip, which I do not want to do. Wondering if I can connect Pin 1 of <CHIP>U6855</CHIP> to <SIGNAL>TPAD_3V3_SPI_INT_L</SIGNAL>, or some similar signal to make it work? Any ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no keyboard or trackpad
threads.message:
KB/TP work in USB mode, before loading macOS (boot menu)?

Keep out <CHIP>U6855</CHIP> and bypass <RESISTOR>R6854</RESISTOR> pads.
Let see if this tricks the T2.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no keyboard or trackpad
threads.message:
No the trackpad does not work even in boot menu. 

I did what you said, but still same thing. No keyboard or trackpad

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no keyboard or trackpad
threads.message:
TP SPI data lines don't go directly to T2.
But who knows, level shifters may got damaged and affected T2 too.

Maintain the bypass and try changing <CHIP>U6860</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no keyboard or trackpad
threads.message: I tried another trackpad from an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> because I was not sure if the trackpad I was testing with was actually good or not. With the <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> trackpad, it works in the boot menu, but then does not work in the OS or recovery mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no keyboard or trackpad
threads.message:
macOS accesses TP through SPI bus and you have missing the required enable signal.
Did you test maintaining <RESISTOR>R6854</RESISTOR> bypass?
